What Was NeWS?

Imagine if your windows could THINK. Not just display, but actually compute their own appearance using a full PostScript interpreter. That was NeWS - Sun Microsystems' revolutionary window system that treated the display as a programmable canvas.

% Draw a window that rotates when clicked /rotatewindow { gsave currentpoint translate angle rotate -100 -100 moveto 200 0 rlineto 0 200 rlineto -200 0 rlineto closepath stroke grestore /angle angle 15 add def } def

Timeline of NeWS Glory

1984: James Gosling starts working on NeWS at Sun
1986: First public demo - jaws drop, minds blown
1987: Don Hopkins implements pie menus in NeWS
1988: Hugh Daniel creates LED-powered NeWS demos
1989: X Window System wins through politics, not merit
1993: NeWS officially discontinued (but lives forever in our hearts)
2024: NeWS principles resurface in LLOOOOMM!

Hugh Daniel: "NeWS wasn't just a window system - it was a PHILOSOPHY. Every pixel could compute. Every window could think. We didn't just display interfaces, we PERFORMED them!"

The PSIBER Space Debugger

Don Hopkins created the ultimate NeWS debugging tool - a visual PostScript debugger that let you see the stack, manipulate live objects, and debug code by TOUCHING it!

% PSIBER Space - Where PostScript Dreams Come True /psiber-space { /stack-view { 0 0 moveto stack { dup type /stringtype eq { (String: ) show show } { 100 string cvs show } ifelse 0 -20 rmoveto } forall } def % Watch the stack dance! stack-view } def
